text.headline: Creation of Unix
text.text: Ken Thompson and Dennis Ritchie develop Unix at AT&T Bell Labs, laying the foundation for future operating systems.

media.caption: Ken Thompson (sitting) and Dennis Ritchie (standing) working together at a PDP-11 mainframe computer.

text.headline: Unix Rewritten in C
text.text: Unix is rewritten in the C programming language, enhancing its portability across different machines.

text.headline: Launch of the GNU Project
text.text: Richard Stallman initiates the GNU Project, aiming to create a free Unix-like operating system.

media.caption: Richard Stallman, founder of the GNU project.

text.headline: Release of MINIX
text.text: Andrew S. Tanenbaum releases MINIX, an educational Unix-like system that inspires Linus Torvalds. It was created as tool to teach OS theory before there were so many free alternatives to teach UNIX-like operating systems.

media.caption: MINIX may longer be maintained, but it succeeded resoundingly in achieving its goal!

text.headline: Announcement of Linux
text.text: Linus Torvalds announces his project to create a free operating system kernel, which becomes Linux.

text.headline: Linux Under GPL
text.text: Linux is relicensed under the GNU General Public License, allowing for free distribution and modification.

text.headline: Release of Linux 1.0
text.text: The first official version of the Linux kernel, version 1.0, is released.

media.caption: Torvalds pictured with Tux, the Linux Mascot, visible on his laptop

text.headline: Adoption of Tux as Mascot
text.text: Tux, the penguin, is chosen as the official mascot for Linux.

text.headline: Major Companies Support Linux
text.text: Companies like IBM, Oracle, and others announce support for Linux, boosting its credibility in the enterprise sector.

text.headline: Release of Ubuntu
text.text: Canonical Ltd. releases Ubuntu, a user-friendly Linux distribution that gains widespread popularity.

text.headline: Introduction of Android
text.text: Google announces Android, a mobile operating system based on the Linux kernel.

text.headline: Linux Dominates Supercomputers
text.text: Linux runs on over 90% of the world's top supercomputers, showcasing its performance and scalability.

text.headline: Steam for Linux Released
text.text: Valve releases a Linux version of its Steam client, expanding gaming possibilities on Linux platforms.

text.headline: Microsoft Adds Linux to Windows
text.text: Windows Subsystem for Linux (WSL) is introduced, allowing Linux to run inside Windows natively.

text.headline: Linux Runs on 100% of Top Supercomputers
text.text: All of the world's top 500 supercomputers run on Linux, highlighting its dominance in high-performance computing.
